div.h1: Traduco: A collaborative web-based CAT environment for the interpretation and translation of texts

div.p: Emiliano Giovannetti, Davide Albanesi, Andrea Bellandi, Giulia Benotto, Traduco: A collaborative web-based CAT environment for the interpretation and translation of texts, Digital Scholarship in the Humanities, Volume 32, Issue suppl_1, April 2017, Pages i47–i62, https://doi.org/10.1093/llc/fqw054

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

optgroup.label: Search within this journal
optgroup.option: All Digital Scholarship in the Humanities

section.p: Traduco is a web-based collaborative tool aimed at supporting the translation of texts that pose particular challenging interpretative issues. Nowadays, Computer-Assisted Translation (CAT) tools are mainly applied to the translation of technical manuals or legislative texts and are aimed at speeding up the translation process. Traduco extends most of the standard components of a traditional CAT tool with specific features necessary to support the interpretation and translation of complex texts (like the Babylonian Talmud, that we here present as a case study), which pose particular comprehension issues. Traduco goes beyond the translation and its printing: it includes features for the addition of notes and annotations and the creation of glossaries. Translators, editors, supervisors, and end-users accessing Traduco are able to use components that can ease the translation process through the use of CAT technologies, the supervision and managing of the whole process of translation and publishing, the exporting of translations and notes in standard formats for desktop publishing software and TEI format, and, soon, the possibility to perform automatic linguistic analysis of the text. Moreover, Traduco allows the users to insert notes, comments, annotations, and bibliographical references. The design and development of Traduco required the adoption of a multidisciplinary approach, leveraging on advances in software engineering, computational linguistics, knowledge engineering, and publishing.

div.p: Traduco is a web-based collaborative tool aimed at supporting the translation of texts that pose particularly challenging interpretative issues. The development of Traduco was started in 2012 at the Institute for Computational Linguistics ‘A. Zampolli’ of the Italian National Research Council (ILC-CNR) for the translation of the Babylonian Talmud (BT) into Italian within the context of the ‘Progetto Traduzione del Talmud Babilonese’ (PTTB), monitored by the Italian Presidency of the Council of Ministers and coordinated by the Union of Italian Jewish Communities and the Italian Rabbinical College.

Nowadays, many Computer-Assisted Translation (CAT) tools—both commercial and free of charge—are already available.1 Professional translators use Translation Memories (TMs) on a regular basis (Lagoudaki 2009). The best-known commercial systems are Across,2 Déjà Vu,3 memoQ,4 MultiTrans,5 SDL Trados,6 Similis,7 Transit,8 and Wordfast9; while non-commercial ones are OpenTM,10 OmegaT,11 Olanto,12 Transolution,13 and Matecat.14 They are mainly applied to the translation of technical manuals or legislative texts and are aimed at speeding up the translation process, allowing translators to save a significant amount of time and effort.

The approach adopted for the development of Traduco is instead more oriented towards covering aspects related to the specific needs of the translator community working on texts with particular interpretative issues. To translate these texts, a translator is required to have two kinds of competences: in language (as a translator) and in the ‘content’ of the text to be translated (as a scholar). Since a portion of text (and sometimes even a single word) can be difficult to interpret and translate, the possibility provided by a collaborative environment to instantly consult translations done by others becomes a necessity. From the end-user’s point of view, the understanding of these texts requires a translation to be enriched with explanations, notes, and glossary entries.

Although some of the cited tools integrate Machine Translation (MT) techniques, the lack of linguistically annotated resources and large collections of parallel texts involving the source and the target languages has prevented us from considering any statistical MT toolkit. Instead, we have implemented a TM enabling translators to re-elaborate the plain and literal translation of the text and to integrate it with explicative additions. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first application of CAT technologies specifically designed to support the translation of complex texts like the BT.

In this article, we describe the main characteristics of Traduco (Section 2) and we discuss all the features that make it different from other CAT tools (Section 3). As a matter of fact, although initially designed to provide basic support in the collaborative translation of the Talmud, over the years Traduco has undergone several upgrades. Some of these involve the integration of state-of-the-art approaches aimed at improving the performance of the Translation Memory System (TMS), the component devoted to suggesting translations to users (Section 4).

At the current stage of development, Traduco is almost ready to be released as an open-source language and text-independent web collaborative environment for the translation of scholarly challenging texts. However, we intend to continue to release new versions, with the integration of new features, as we shall briefly discuss in Section 5.

Traduco is made up of various components, each implementing specific functionalities targeted at different types of users (Fig. 1). The system goes beyond the mere translation and its printing: it includes features for the addition of notes and annotations and the creation of glossaries. Translators, editors, supervisors, and end-users accessing Traduco will therefore be able to use components that can:
General architecture of Traduco
General architecture of Traduco

li.p: ease the translation process through the use of CAT technologies, including indexers and TM tools (see Section 3.1.);
allow the users to insert notes, comments, annotations, and bibliographical references (see Section 3.2);
supervise and manage the whole process of translation and publishing (see Section 3.3);
export translations and notes in standard formats for desktop publishing software and Text Encoding Initiative (TEI) format (see Section 3.4);
perform automatic linguistic analysis of the text (see Section 4).

div.p: The following two subsections describe both the general architecture of Traduco and the technical solutions adopted for its implementation.

From a technical point of view, Traduco was designed as a group of independent web-based components connected by interfaces. It is based on the software design pattern known as ‘three-tier architecture’, and it exploits Apache Tomcat v7.0 as web server. The component-based architectural structure was implemented by the object-oriented J2SE framework, enhanced with Contexts and Dependency Injection annotations, using the Weld v2.2.4 reference implementation. Relational persistence and query services are managed by Hibernate v4.3.7, which is responsible for the mapping from Java classes to the Mysql v5.0 database tables. To provide a very responsive TMS component we adopted an inverted index data structure (Patil et al., 2011). Finally, the presentation layer was implemented with JavaServer Faces, a framework for building component-based user interfaces for web applications based on the Mojarra Oracle implementation v2.2.9 and using the Primefaces v5.1 library.

Traduco extends most of the standard components of a traditional CAT tool with specific features necessary to support the interpretation and translation of texts like the BT, which pose particular comprehension issues. The design and development of Traduco required the adoption of a multidisciplinary approach, leveraging on advances in software engineering, computational linguistics, knowledge engineering, publishing, and, in the case of its application to the translation of the BT, on Talmudic knowledge and Ancient Semitic linguistics.

The basic functioning of Traduco is not different from other CAT tools. As shown in Fig. 2, a translator can view the hierarchical structure (on the left) of the translated text—organized, in the case of the BT, in tractates, chapters, blocks, logical units, and strings (the segments). In the central part of the table, a translator can insert new segments paired with their translations, either manually one after the other, or by creating multiple segments all at once and then translating them separately. Just above the translation table, a collapsible ‘Filter’ section allows the users to execute searches, both on the source and on the translated texts. Finally, on the right of the table there are the notes, glossary entries, and translation suggestions relative to the selected pair of segments.

img.alt: Main interface of Traduco. (a) hierarchical structure of the translated text; (b) translation table and filter; (c) translation references: notes, glossary entries, translation suggestions

div.p: Main interface of Traduco. (a) hierarchical structure of the translated text; (b) translation table and filter; (c) translation references: notes, glossary entries, translation suggestions

img.alt: Main interface of Traduco. (a) hierarchical structure of the translated text; (b) translation table and filter; (c) translation references: notes, glossary entries, translation suggestions

div.p: Main interface of Traduco. (a) hierarchical structure of the translated text; (b) translation table and filter; (c) translation references: notes, glossary entries, translation suggestions

Traduco can support in the translation of complex texts often requiring specific reformulations so as to be correctly understood by non-scholars. Figure 3 shows how the translation of each segment can be performed by differentiating the ‘literal’ translation (in bold) from explicative additions, i.e. ‘contextual information’. Segments having the same literal part can then differ by their contextual information. The tractate of the source segment of each translation is called ‘context’.

img.alt: Example of literal translations (bold font) and contextual information (plain font)

div.p: Example of literal translations (bold font) and contextual information (plain font)

img.alt: Example of literal translations (bold font) and contextual information (plain font)

div.p: Example of literal translations (bold font) and contextual information (plain font)

In the following subsections we outline the most relevant features implemented by the components of Traduco that have been developed to face the translation of textual corpora with complex philological and linguistic peculiarities, as in the case of the BT.

Given a segment sq to be translated, the TMS returns a translation tq by searching the TM for the best match, i.e. a pair (s, tq) whose similarity Sim(s, sq) ≥ σ is maximal, if it exists (Sikes 2007). The function Sim measures the similarity between two source-language segments. Typically, it produces a percentage value, where 100% stands for ‘identical segments’, i.e. exact match, and 0% for ‘completely different segments’. Intermediate percentage values are called fuzzy matches. The TMS ranks suggestion by similarities and presents them to translators. Typically, when there is not an exact match, the translator needs to edit the proposed suggestions. The next subsections describe how the system retrieves pertinent translation suggestions (see Section 3.1.2), and how the system presents the suggestions to each translator (see Section 3.1.3).

It is well known that most TMSs are based on variants of the ‘Levenshtein’ distance normalized over the length of the query segment, i.e. the minimum number of edit operations required to transform a string into another one. In the case of the BT, we did not take into account variants aware of linguistic information, since no available NLP tools are suitable for processing ancient North-western Semitic languages, such as the different Hebrew and Aramaic idioms attested in the BT (see Section 4).

We chose to adopt a similarity measure Sim based on edit distance, ED(s1, s2), considering two segments to be more similar when the same terms tend to appear in the same order. Given an sq segment to be translated, the formula in Figure 4 measures the similarity between sq and a segment s16.
Similarity function
Similarity function

One of the novelties we introduced is the way in which suggestions are ranked. In particular, we consider (1) the authors of translations and (2) the context (the tractate of reference). The information about the author of the translation and of the tractate of reference is useful both for translators and revisors. On the one hand, translators are enabled to evaluate the reliability of the suggested translations on the basis of the authority and expertise of the relative translators. On the other hand, revisors can exploit both kinds of information to ensure a more homogeneous and fluent translation.
Our algorithm is based on dynamic programming, and its implementation refers to (Navarro 2001). To compute ED(s1, s2), it builds a matrix M(0.|s1|,0.|s2|),

where each element mi,j represents the minimum number of token mutations required to transform s1(1.i) in s2(1.j). The computation process is indicated in Figure 5, where μ = min(m(i − 1,j), m(i,j − 1), m(i − 1,j − 1)), and the final cost is represented by m(|s1|,|s2|). The TMS returns the translated strings having the lower costs. Basically, given a segment to be translated, many other source segments can equal it exactly and each of these segments can be paired with multiple translations in the TM. Figure 6 shows an example of ED(s1,s2) computation. Thanks to the technical solutions described in Section 2.2, the TMS can retrieve and present the translation suggestions in only a few milliseconds.
Computation process of ED(s1, s2)
Computation process of ED(s1, s2)

img.alt: Example of ED(s1, s2) computation. m(|s1|,|s2|) = 3

div.p: Example of ED(s1, s2) computation. m(|s1|,|s2|) = 3

img.alt: Example of ED(s1, s2) computation. m(|s1|,|s2|) = 3

div.p: Example of ED(s1, s2) computation. m(|s1|,|s2|) = 3

The Traduco user interface shows each suggestion accompanied by a number of stars, as appears in Fig. 7. The number is assigned on the basis of how fuzzy the match between source segments is: five-star suggestions are considered perfect (exact match, Sim = 100%); four stars indicate that a few corrections are probably required (fuzzy match, 85% ≤ Sim ≤ 99%); and three stars indicate, in most cases, acceptable suggestions (weak fuzzy match, 70% ≤ Sim ≤ 84%). The TMS orders by context and by author the suggestions that are ranked with the same number of stars. Each translator, for example, can then approve as correct the literal translation τ ji, and modify only τ ji.
Translation suggestion process
Translation suggestion process

A translator can choose to filter the proposed suggestions to visualize just his/her own translations, revised translations or translations belonging to the particular tractate on which (s)he is working. Of course, each new translation is added to the TM, thus increasing the pool of translations available.

The evaluation of the performance of a system like Traduco is not a trivial task. Unlike a typical CAT tool, the aim of Traduco is not limited to increasing the translation pace, but it is meant to support the translation process by offering a collaborative environment in which users can translate their own portions of texts by exploiting the translation of similar source segments (that could greatly differ in the explicative additions) done by others.

Before undergoing an empirical evaluation, we analysed the redundancy of the TM by considering the similar segments. To estimate the TM performance we conducted a jackknife experiment (Wu 1986). We partitioned the TM in groups of 1,000; we then used each group as a test set and translated its source segments using the rest of the TM. We repeated the process n times. Intuitively, this resampling method uses the variability in the test sets to draw conclusions about statistical significance. Figure 8 shows the redundancy rate of the TM from the beginning of the project to the 20th month. Redundancy curves are drawn by considering the ranking of the similarity function. The percentage of source segments found in the TM grows logarithmically with time (and consequently with the size of the memory): the larger is the memory, the better will be the performance. For instance, if we suppose that exact matches provide at least one perfect suggestion, then each translator would save 30% of their work time.
TMS performance
TMS performance

The translation of texts raising particular interpretative issues requires additional features going beyond the mere translation. First, as anticipated in Section 3 (Fig. 3), a translation meant to be comprehensible to non-experts can require the inclusion of explicative integrations (constituting interpretations in themselves). In addition, it can be necessary to annotate the translated text at various levels. Traduco allows translators to (1) insert different types of notes of different types (generic notes, revision notes, editorial notes, etc.) as shown in Fig. 9a., (2) semantically annotate arbitrary portions of text (Fig. 9b.), and (3) insert partially precompiled bibliographic references (e.g. for biblical citations to be completed with chapter and verse numbers) and names of Rabbis.

img.alt: The rich text editor of Traduco. (a) Example of insertion of notes; (b) Example of semantic annotation

div.p: The rich text editor of Traduco. (a) Example of insertion of notes; (b) Example of semantic annotation

img.alt: The rich text editor of Traduco. (a) Example of insertion of notes; (b) Example of semantic annotation

div.p: The rich text editor of Traduco. (a) Example of insertion of notes; (b) Example of semantic annotation

For the translation of the BT, Traduco allows translators to annotate the translated (Italian) text on the basis of a set of seven predefined semantic classes: people’s names, Rabbis’ names, nature (plants, animals, etc.), measures, idiomatic expressions (e.g. ‘the Master said’), linguistic expressions, and concepts (e.g. ‘Terumah’). Each semantic annotation can be accompanied by a free textual description (see the ‘Glossaries’ panel on the right of Fig. 2c.), an optional transliteration and an optional Hebrew original form. A new annotation can be associated with a canonical form by referring to an existing glossary entry.

Each annotated portion of text constitutes a glossary entry: a dedicated panel of the system (Fig. 10) allows the browsing and querying of all the entries, each of which is shown with its description (glossa) and all its references in the text.
The glossaries panel
The glossaries panel

The availability of a sufficiently large number of annotations paves the way to the automatization of the annotation process. By exploiting the automatic linguistic analysis of the translated text (see Section 4.1) it should be possible to implement a stochastic supervised algorithm, trained on the available annotations, to suggest candidate annotations that users can accept or reject. Moreover, as described in Section 6, the terminology constituting the various glossary entries could be exploited to build a Talmudic Knowledge Base using a formal knowledge representation language.

Traduco allows supervisors to profile different types of users assembled in a ‘team’ (composed of ‘translators’, ‘revisors’, ‘editors’, and ‘supervisors’ themselves, in its instantiation for the translation of the Talmud) with the precise purpose of collaborative translation and publishing of a specific text. Each user can have one or more roles and specific rights on the system. Furthermore, each user is associated with one or more ‘resources’, i.e. specific portions of the text to be translated (for example, a single chapter).

Each resource (in the case of the Talmud, a tractate, chapter, block, or logical unit) has a ‘state of progress’ represented as a sort of ‘traffic light’ (Fig. 11), where red stands for ‘not assigned’, yellow for ‘in progress’, and green for ‘completed’. From left to right, the three bullets represent the state of the translation, the revision, and the editing. The change of state is permitted to users according to their rights. Translators, for example, can only alter the state of translation (the leftmost bullet) and are limited by the resources they have been assigned.

img.alt: Translation state of progress indicators; in this example, the logical unit with id 2.1.15.1 has been translated, revised, and edited, while the block it belongs (2.1.15) to is still being edited (the rightmost bullet appears in a lighter colour)

div.p: Translation state of progress indicators; in this example, the logical unit with id 2.1.15.1 has been translated, revised, and edited, while the block it belongs (2.1.15) to is still being edited (the rightmost bullet appears in a lighter colour)

img.alt: Translation state of progress indicators; in this example, the logical unit with id 2.1.15.1 has been translated, revised, and edited, while the block it belongs (2.1.15) to is still being edited (the rightmost bullet appears in a lighter colour)

div.p: Translation state of progress indicators; in this example, the logical unit with id 2.1.15.1 has been translated, revised, and edited, while the block it belongs (2.1.15) to is still being edited (the rightmost bullet appears in a lighter colour)

The whole translation workflow can be supervised through a dedicated panel (Fig. 12). Figure 12a., for example, shows an administrator checking on the progress of a resource by monitoring the productivity of all user types. By means of a graphical representation it is also possible to examine the overall advancement of the different state of progress (translation, revising, and editing) of the selected resource (see Fig. 12b.).

img.alt: The Traduco workflow control panel (usernames are clouded for privacy reasons). (a) analytical data by user. (b) data summary in graphical form

div.p: The Traduco workflow control panel (usernames are clouded for privacy reasons). (a) analytical data by user. (b) data summary in graphical form

img.alt: The Traduco workflow control panel (usernames are clouded for privacy reasons). (a) analytical data by user. (b) data summary in graphical form

div.p: The Traduco workflow control panel (usernames are clouded for privacy reasons). (a) analytical data by user. (b) data summary in graphical form

In addition to the functionalities for the translation, annotation, creation of glossaries, and the overall management of the workflow, Traduco includes a number of tools designed to export the translated texts in various formats.

For the translation of the Talmud, the system allows users to export a selected resource (from a single logical unit to a whole tractate) in four different pdf formats. Furthermore, to assist in the production of the printed edition, it is possible to export the translation, the notes, and the glossaries in Adobe InDesign XML schema.17

An exporter in TEI format is currently under development. The TEI guidelines collectively defined an XML format differing from other well-known open formats for text in that it is primarily semantic rather than presentational; the semantics and interpretation of each tag and attribute are specified.

For Traduco, we chose to adopt the TEIbook scheme,18 which is a restriction of the TEI P5 guidelines, aimed at representing the structure of printed books. This profile has been designed in reference to HTML 5 (to guarantee the conservation of HTML semantics) and it can encode all the information generated by word processing. It aims to produce quality electronic publishing (ePub TOC, online site), while allowing subsequent semantic enrichment.

In this chapter, we introduce some of the most innovative features of Traduco that are currently under development. In particular, we describe the integration of language technologies, including NLP for the analysis of the source and target languages (Section 4.1) and Distributional Semantics (DS) for the boosting of the TMS component (Section 4.2).

In an ideal situation, where both the source and the target language are well-served by linguistic analysis tools and resources, it is expected that NLP will be applied to analyse the text being translated and the produced translation. However, especially in the translation of ancient texts, the target language only is more likely to be analysed, as it happened to us with the Italian BT.

For the translation of the Talmud, we have equipped Traduco with an experimental component for the automatic linguistic analysis of Italian. Every time a translation is submitted (or modified), the system analyses it and assigns, to each ‘token’, a lemma and a part-of-speech. Then, the translator (or, lately, a revisor) can edit and correct errors in the analysis (Fig. 13).
In this first version, the morphological traits are not shown, to avoid overloading the user's revision work.

In the literature, there are two main kinds of approaches for maximizing the function Sim in Fig. 13: those leveraging on MT confidence measures (Dong et al., 2014; He et al. 2010a,b; Koehn and Senellart, 2010; Smith and Clark, 2009; Wang et al., 2014), and those going beyond the simple surface form comparison by introducing linguistic information and paraphrasing (Ganitkevitch et al., 2013; Gupta and Orăsan, 2014; Hodász and Pohl 2005; Pekar and Ruslan, 2007; Planas and Furuse, 1999; Utiyama et al., 2011).
The linguistic analysis editing interface
The linguistic analysis editing interface

However, as said before, there are situations in which no NLP tools or linguistic resources are available for undertaking any kind of linguistic analysis. In the case of the BT, for example, apart from some tools for the analysis of Modern Hebrew like MILA (Itai 2006), and HebMorph,19 the processing of ancient North-western Semitic languages is by no means supported. To (partially) obviate to the lack of linguistic resources and tools, we have developed a technique based on DS to boost the TMS component and improve the quality of suggestions.

The kinds of relations involving word pairs found by the algorithm have been reported in Table 1.
Table 1
Types of relations found out by the DS algorithm
Type of relation . Found . Example .
Idiomatic 23 Words having the same meaning but written in different languages, typically Hebrew and Aramaic, e.g. the words and translated into ‘adatti’ (‘suitable’)
Orthographic 5 Words appearing in different writings, e.g. the words and translated into ‘campanelli’ (‘bells’)
Morphological 21 Words having the same root but different flexions, e.g. the words and meaning ‘exits’, and ‘will exit’ translated into ‘esce’ (‘exits’)
Syntactic 62 Words with or without articles or conjunctions, due to the agglutinating nature of the involved Semitic idioms, e.g. the word meaning ‘place’, and the word meaning ‘the place’, and words appearing in distinct sentences with a different order, e.g. and meaning ‘Rabbi Papà said’ and ‘said Rabbi Papà’, respectively
Lexico-semantic 23 Words involved in synonymic or quasi-synonymic relations, e.g. the word meaning ‘to put’ and meaning ‘to place’ or meaning ‘on behalf of’ and meaning ‘as a representative of’.

Before undergoing an empirical evaluation of this approach, it is already possible to observe how the DS-boosted measure tends naturally to reduce the cost of the Edit() function (i.e. by increasing the Sim function) between two source segments in proportion of the similarity of the differing words. Therefore, the percentage values of fuzzy matches can increase, and consequently (1) some translation suggestions can go up in the ranking of the TMS, and (2) new suggestions, which otherwise would have not been retrieved, can be proposed.

This technique inherits the limits of DS approaches, i.e. their ability to discover relations among words sharing similar contexts is proportional to the size of the analysed corpus. In the case of this experiment the selected corpus—although a relatively small portion of the BT—was large enough to provide significative results. However, being an unsupervised, linguistically agnostic approach, it can be applied to other source languages and texts. Consequently, it can be particularly useful in translations involving languages that are not supported by NLP tools and resources, since it permits to retrieve segments differing in morphological and/or syntactic word variants from the one being translated.

Concerning the evaluation of the improvement obtained by the introduction of the DS-boosted measures we expect a number of issues. First of all, the reference corpora that are typically used in literature to evaluate the performance of a TMS appear very different from the BT (especially in terms of lexical variety). Evaluations based on post-editing and keystrokes appear to be not suitable for our translation context. Indeed, the translation of a new segment which has been (even partially) already translated, can be significantly different and require, for example, a greater number of words in the target segment to correctly explain the sentence in a different context. Finally, the Talmud shows a very high variability while translating identical source segments, w.r.t. other corpora. For example, similar segments can require really different translation times, for example, when one of them contains peculiar words that have to be properly explained using an annotation.
In addition, Traduco will soon provide linguistic-based access to the translation and suggestions boosted by DS.

From a more general point of view, considering the aforementioned features, we propose Traduco as the ideal (though still being improved) CAT tool for the translation of humanistic texts that, being complex and hermeneutically challenging, (1) need to be translated by a team of users and (2) need to be enriched by a number of explicative notes and glossaries to be fully understood by readers. In other words, adopting Traduco for the translation of a ‘standard’ literary work (as a novel written in a modern language) by a single translator could be a nonsense.

Following the integration of the aforementioned linguistic-based technologies, we will focus our attention on the content of the text. The analysis of the results coming from the semantic annotation of the Talmud suggested the idea of providing a formal structuring to the concepts related to the annotated terms and entities. Indeed, a formalized, machine processable representation of the content of a text (for example, modelled with an ontology) allows to browse the text with ‘semantic queries’, and not just by keyword or, as described in the Section 4.1.1, on a linguistic basis. Some preliminary experiments have already been documented in Bellandi et al. (2014).

Although implemented in a research context, Traduco is solid and flexible enough to be easily customized for the translation of other texts and in other languages. As a matter of fact, in the last 3 years, Traduco has been used, collaboratively, by the PTTB team composed of more than forty users, who have extensively tested the system in all its different functionalities.
A demo version of Traduco (accompanied by a detailed user’s guide) can be tested at the following url: http://talmud-dev.ilc.cnr.it:8082/talmud/21

This work was supported by the project TALMUD and carried out in the context of the scientific partnership between S.c.a r.l. ‘Progetto Traduzione del Talmud Babilonese’ and ILC-CNR and on the basis of the regulations stated in the ‘Protocollo d’Intesa’ (memorandum of understanding) between the Italian Presidency of the Council of Ministers, the Italian Ministry of Education, Universities and Research, the Union of Italian Jewish Communities, the Italian Rabbinical College, and the Italian National Research Council (21 January 2011).
